Супруг работает охранником в детском саду и имеет определенную зарплату. У Айнагул - среднее образование, она очень энергичная, жизнерадостная. В качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Айнагул занимается животноводством, стартовав 35 лет назад, с покупки скота на 10,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Айнагул, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 4 дойные коровы. Ежемесячный доход составляет 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Айнагул обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом - на покупку коровы для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Айнагул планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства в помощь сыну на строительство дома.
texts.en: Ainagul is 54 years old, married and raising 3 children together with her husband. Two of her older sons are married and live separately with their families, and the youngest lives with Ainagul.  Her husband works as a security guard at a kindergarten and has a set salary.  Ainagul has a secondary education; she is very energetic and happy. To provide the primary income for her family, she is involved in animal husbandry, having started 35 years ago with a purchase of livestock with 10,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Ainagul's hard work, today her business contains 4 dairy cows. The monthly income amounts to 10,000 som (KGS). In order to further develop her business, Ainagul requested a loan from the microfinance bank "Bai-Tushum and Partners" to buy a cow in order to increase livestock headcount. Ainagul plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further increasing domestic livestock quantities and saving money to help her son build a house.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Ibrohimjon

texts.en: Ibrohimjon was born in 1983. He lives with his family in a rural area. He is married and has two little children. Ibrohimjon’s wife is a seamstress. He has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 10 years. Ibrohimjon has great experience. He uses the profit from his business to provide his family with all necessary things. He is going to organize a party but he has no money. He is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to organize a party. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To organize a party

loans.name: Kamoliddin

texts.en: Kamoliddin was born in 1971. He is married and has two little children. Kamoliddin is a hardworking man. Kamoliddin has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 15 years. He buys cows, feeds them for six months and sells them in a local market. His wife has been busy with growing agricultural products. Kamoliddin is the main income earner in his family. He is a repeat client of IMON. He has a good story. He wants to repair his house as his house is in bad condition but he does not have enough money. He is asking for a loan of 12,000 Somoni to buy building materials such as cement and wood for repairing his house. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy building materials including cement and wood for repairing his house

loans.name: Malika

texts.en: Malika is a young woman from the south part of Tajikistan. She sells mobile telephones in a store. She has been busy with this business for more than a year. Malika successfully manages the business and has her regular customers. She wants to develop her business further. She is asking for a loan with this aim. Malika is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to buy mobile telephones to increase her capital. This loan will help her to develop business and to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy mobile telephones to increase her capital.

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en: Mavjuda is 51 years old. She is a widow and careful mother of three children. She is the main income earner in her family. She has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 15 years. She has great experience in this field. Mavjuda began her business with three sheep. Now she runs her business perfectly. She works hard from early morning till late evening. She is going to organize a party but she has no money. She is asking for a loan of 4000 Somoni to organize a party.

loans.use: To organize a party

loans.name: Zohida

texts.en:
Zohida is going to start her own business in animal husbandry. She lives in a village and that’s why she has a good opportunity to develop her business. With this aim, Zohida took part in a course ‘To get Ahead’ run by a woman's organization and got a certificate. She took part very actively, and got a lot of useful information for managing a business. 

Zohida is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni to buy cattle for starting her new business. She awaits your support. 

She is not married.

loans.use: to buy cattle for starting her new business.

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.en: Nargiza is divorced. She has been bringing up her son Shohjahon alone. She lives with her parents and brothers. She has been busy with her own business for more than 10 years. She sells perfumes in a local market. Nargiza works hard. She has regular customers. She wants to bring up her son without any problems. She wants to build a house for herself and her son but she does not have enough money. She is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to buy building materials such as cement, wood and soil. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement, wood and soil for building a house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a married man, aged forty seven years, with six children. He lives in a rural area with his family and his children are 18, 16,14,12,10, and 8 years old. Four of his children go to school.
Julius is a businessman who deals in produce trading and he has been in this business since 1997.  He works seven days in a week and each day he works for 12 hours.
He started this business in order to earn a living and he has acquired a loan so that he can boost his business by increasing his stock since people have started to harvest.
He says his clients are fellow traders from around areas and he hopes to build a big store for his products and start selling in large quantities. 
He says that like any other business, he faces the challenge of low market prices and lack of sufficient capital to sustain the business throughout all seasons. He describes himself as a hard working and honest man and appreciates the work of Ugafode in supporting them.

loans.use: to buy produce for resale.

loans.name: Gezim

texts.en:
Gezim, whose name means “Joy” in English, wants to buy seedlings for planting with this loan. For the past fifteen years, Gezim’s focus has been on his cherry and plum orchard and selling the fruits to wholesalers/buyers. 
“It hasn’t been bad at all. It’s a good business and, of course, has its' ups and downs just like any type of agricultural activity. Sometimes the weather and other times the insects can cause damage to the trees and fruits, but anyhow, I want to focus on the benefits. In addition to the orchard, I also have livestock, but on a smaller scale.”
Gezim is in his fifties, married and has two children

loans.use: to buy cherry and plum seedlings for planting

loans.name: Shahzodakhon

texts.en:
Shahzodakhon was born in 1960. She is married and has adult children. 

Shahzodakhon’s husband has been busy with keeping bees. She has her own business feeding cattle in her cowshed. Shahzodakhon has a stable business and source of income. 

She must organize a party but she has no money. She is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni to organize a party. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to organize a party.

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina is a 46-year-old married woman who has been running a business selling milk with her husband for many years. She has three cows and one buffalo, which she uses for milk to sell to the people of her locality. She also sells butter and cheese to generate an extra amount of profit. 

Zarina has become famous for providing good-quality milk and makes enough to contribute to her family's income. She has gradually improved her business with the support of the Kashf Foundation. Currently she is in her seventh loan cycle, and has now applied for a loan of PKR 50,000. This will allow her to purchase one more cow. Zarina is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her and will bring positive changes to her business.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow.

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: Rubina is a 40-year-old married woman. She has been running a business making and selling samosas. A samosa is a fried or baked pastry with a savory filling, such as spiced potatoes, onions, peas, lentils or chicken.  She is expert in making good tasting samosas and earns enough through this business to contribute to the family income. In order to increase her sales she needs to purchase packs of flour, oil, salt and spices so she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR. She is in her fifth loan cycle with a good repayment history. She wants to spend part of her inocome on providing her children with a quality education.

loans.use: to purchase packs of flour, oil, salt and spices.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: Nasreen is 41 years old, married and the mother of five children. The man shown in the photo is Nasreen’s husband who is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. He has been driving a rickshaw for many years to meet the family expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it functioning. For this reason, Nasreen has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR for her husband. He wants to buy new tires for his vehicle. This will help him drive more smoothly and provide a better transport service to his passengers. Nasreen is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

loans.use: to buy new tires for her husband's vehicle.

loans.name: Nazir

texts.en: Nazir, age 51, has a business buying and selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, brings them up and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She needs to improve her business to cover her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase two more baby goats. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income.

loans.use: to purchase two more baby goats.

loans.name: Sarviza

texts.ru:
Сарвиза 33-летняя жительница района Шахритус. Она зарабатывает на жизнь честным трудом. На протяжении 5 лет Сарвиза занимается посевом сельскохозяйственных культур и разведением крупнрогатого скота. В сельских местностях земледелие и животноводство является основными видами деятельности и многие жители сёл, в том числе и Сарвиза занимаются этими деятельностями.
В данный момент муж Сарвизы работает в России и по этой причине она одна занимается воспитанием детей. У них трое детей и Сарвиза с мужем трудятся усердно ради их светлого будущего. Чтобы увеличить поголовье скота, Сарвиза обратилась за кредитом в размере 1200 долларов США. На сумму кредита она собирается закупить пару голов крупнорогатого скота. Она ждет поддержки.
texts.en: Sarviza is a 33 year-old resident of the Shahrituz district.  She earns a living with honest work.  Sarviza has been involved in sowing agricultural crops and breeding cattle for 5 years.  Farming and animal husbandry are the primary types of business in a rural areas, and many village residents, including Sarviza, are involved in these types of businesses.  At the present time, Sarviza's husband works in Russia and this is why she is involved in raising the children by herself.  They have three children, and Sarviza and her husband work hard for their bright future.  Sarviza requested a loan in the amount of 1200 US dollars to increase livestock headcount.  She plans to buy a pair of cattle with the loan amount.  She awaits support.

loans.use: to buy a pair of cattle

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en:
Shazia is a 35-year-old married woman who has been running a business selling milk for many years. She has five cows. She sells milk to many of her neighbors. She also sells animals on a seasonal basis to generate an extra amount of income. Her business is good enough for her to lead a decent life. 

Shazia has six children, and she is very motivated to provide them with a beautiful life with good education, food and clothing. She has improved her business to meet her day to day expenses of life. 

She has applied a loan of Rs. 45,000 to purchase another cow. It’s her fifth year with Kashf Foundation; she is happily running her business with the Foundation's support. She hopes to increase her milk production capacity, which ultimately helps in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase another cow.

loans.name: Noor

texts.en:
Noor is a 51-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband, who is also shown in the photo. She has four years of experience in this field. Her husband also assists her by purchasing goods from the market, as he has maintained many contacts over the years. 

Noor is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing and health. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of PKR 40,000 to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to meet with the increasing demand in her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to sell in her store.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen is a 30-year-old married woman. She has been running a small general store in her community for many years with the support of her husband. She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. Parveen makes enough to provide for her family. 

To make her store fully stocked, she requested a loan of Rs 50,000 which she will use to buy stock of rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. In this way she would be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. Parveen wishes to utilize part of her revenue to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy stock of rice, sugar and flour.

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en:
Nizami is married and has two children. One of them, his 21-year-old daughter, studies at University. Nizami’s son is studying in his first year of college, and his wife is a housewife. They are Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) from the city of Fuzuli and now live in the Ahmadbayli village of Fuzuli region. 

Nizami is a cameraman. He make videos of weddings, birthdays etc. He has been in this business for many years, but now his computer is broken, and he wants to buy a new computer. Therefore, he has applied to Komak company for a loan of 1,500 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). This is Nizami’s third loan. Nizami says thanks to Kiva and its lenders for their help.

loans.use: to buy a new computer.

loans.name: Shameem

texts.en: Shameem is 53 years old, married and the mother of four children. The man shown in the photo is Shameem’s son who is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. He has been driving a rickshaw for many years to meet the family expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it functioning. For this reason, she has applied for a loan of 50,000 PKR for her son. He wants to buy new tires for his vehicle. This will help him drive more smoothly and provide a better transport service to his passengers. She is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her son and will bring positive changes to his business.

loans.use: to buy new tires for her son's vehicle.

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en: Zarina is a 42-year-old married woman. The man shown in the photo is Zarina’s husband who has a hawker's business which is their major source of income. He sells different items like sweets, biscuits and candies on his motorbike to the people of his community. In this way he earns a sufficient income to meet the family expenses. In order to meet their everyday expenditures more income is required so Zarina contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of 45,000 PKR. Her husband will use this loan amount to purchase more packs of biscuits, sweets and candies to increase his sales. Zarina is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

loans.use: and her husband to purchase more packs of biscuits, sweets and candies.

loans.name: Firdous

texts.en:
Firdous is 45 years old and married. She has six children; one of her daughters is shown in photo. Two years ago, she started her business stitching clothes with her daughter to contribute in the family income. She is very familiar with the stitching techniques. She enjoys a great client list and has gained a lot of appreciation and popularity in her community.  

Currently she has requested a loan of Rs 40,000 to buy spools of threads along with packs of needles, laces and zippers. Then she will be able to meet the demands of her customers without fail. She hopes to grow her business and dreams of improving her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy spools of threads along with packs of needles, laces and zippers.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is 46 years old and married. She has been running a business selling bangles for many years. She buys bangles from the wholesale markets at lower rates and then sells them to the people of her community at a profit. Her husband’s income is not enough to fulfill the family needs. Therefore she started her own business to contribute to the family income. 

Nasreen has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. She has now requested a loan of PKR 40,000 to buy the latest varieties of bangles in different colors and designs. This will help her to increase her sales. She is in her seventh loan cycle and has a good repayment history. She wants to expand her business to provide a better standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to buy the latest varieties of bangles in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Muneeran

texts.en: Muneeran is a 52-year-old married woman. She has had an embroidery business for many years. She makes beautiful patterns for the people of her community. Her designs are in great demand and she has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her household. To help her to continue her operations, she has requested a loan of 55,000 PKR to buy reels of threads in different colors along with packs of beads, sequins and stones. In this way she will be able to cater for more customers consistently. She hopes to get an increase in her income by targeting more customers. She is in her eighth loan cycle with a good credit history.

loans.use: to buy reels of threads in different colors along with packs of beads, sequins and stones

loans.name: Fozia

texts.en:
Fozia is a 33-year-old married woman. She has been stitching bags for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to a lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. 

For this reason, she requested a loan of Rs 45,000 from the Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan to buy more spools of threads in different colors, along with packs of zippers and buttons. She hope to create a means of increasing revenue so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her fourth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors, along with packs of  zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy house building materials such as corrugated iron sheets, sand, nails and cement in order to erect a dwelling house for his family

loans.name: Che Isobel

texts.en:
Che Isobel is a widow with six children. They live in a seven bedroom apartment in the Bamenda Mezam Division of the North West Region of Cameroon. She has faced many challenges in life, among which are inadequate capital to successfully carry out her business, sickness in her family, death of close family members, and inadequate finances to educate her children.

She has taken and repaid her loans successfully three times and says with the new loan requested, she will expand her firewood business by buying more wood, and buy maize, drinks for her bar and palm wine. She holds a positive view of her business succeeding because she has been doing it; she has ready customers who buy from her; and she supplies drinks in ceremonial activities like birthdays, marriages, and death celebrations. With this activity the community will have a regular supply at their door steps and at cheaper prices.

With the profit from this business, she will expand her business by reinvesting, cater to her children's needs, and use it for other unforeseen situations. She prefers GHAPE loans because of the low interest rate and convenient repayment intervals.

loans.use: To buy firewood, maize, drinks, and palm wine.

loans.name: Saibaba Shg Group

texts.en:
Manorama is a 41-year-old lady and has two children. In the picture, the lady standing with a raised hand is Manorama. She lives in a small village of Chandikhole, Odisha, India with her husband, parents-in-law and her children. 

A few years back, she started a business of making and selling flour, such as wheat flour, maize flour, gram flour, lentil flour, rice flour, etc. She makes these flours with the help of grinders. She makes a variety of flours, depending on the demand for flour in the market. 

She is requesting a loan amount of 90,000 INR for her group. She will use her portion to buy more supplies, such as wheat, maize, grains, etc., and a new grinder machine. With this investment, she will expand her business so that she can generate more income and improve the quality of life for herself and her family. 

She is requesting within a group of nine members who all are women and all live in the same community. They named their group "Saibaba SHG" Self Help Group (named after lord Saibaba, who they believe will protect them).

Manorama hopes to construct a house for her family in the near future. She wants to say, "Thank you," to Kiva and its lenders across the world for their help and support.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies, such as wheat, maize, grains, etc., and a new grinder machine.

loans.name: Gjysime

texts.en:
Gjysime is a mother of eight children, with one of them being born blind and with a husband who suffers from a serious illness. She lives in a rural village, is in her fifties and is requesting a loan to buy a female baby calf called “mushqerra” in the Albanian language. 

Here it is what Gjysime said to the loan officer during the interview:  “I started the animal husbandry business about twenty years ago, because before under the communist regime of course, we were not given such a chance. I can say that this activity has been our only source of income for all these past years.”  This will be Gjysime’s first loan.

loans.use: to buy a female baby calf called "mushqerra" in Albanian

loans.name: Ann Maa Basumata Shg Group

texts.en:
A 54-year-old mother of four children, Kuntala (in the picture the lady standing with raised hand) is a widow who currently only has one schoolchild under her dependency. As a single mother, she struggles in earning her daily cost of living through selling fish and a small grocery shop. For her eight year involvement in the current business, she is able to earn up to 7,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month.

She is a first-time borrower with People's Forum, Kiva's partner, and feels very confident that she can upgrade her living in a gradual manner.

Now, to better support her business, she formed a group of ten members having the name Ann Maa Basumata SHG to request a loan. All the group members are female and all are engaged in different business activities like fish selling, vegetable selling, paddy cultivation etc. The total of her group loan loan is 250,000 INR. Kuntala will use her loan portion to buy grocery items to support her business. Moreover, she also wants to fix her house so it is in proper condition.

She hopes her business will improve progressively, and also hopes to have her house in good condition.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items in bulk like sugar, rice, raw dal, spices, biscuits, tea, flour etc. to support her business.

loans.name: Minati

texts.en:
Minati is a 38-year-old hardworking lady of a small village of Dhupguri in Jalpaiguri district. She stays with her husband and two children. One is in class IX (grade 9) and other is in class VII (grade 7).  Minati and her husband are illiterate but know how to sign their name. Her husband is a van puller, working under a local owner, so the income is not sufficient to meet the educational expenses of their children and also household expenses.
 
Minati’s son, Krishna, is a meritorious student and the best boy in his class. If he could get private coaching then he could do much better in his final examination. All the teachers of his school are waiting for his outstanding result in final examination. Minati seeks this loan to support her son’s education so that he does not face any difficulty in receiving education. 

This loan would help her to pay the tuition fees, to purchase educational equipment like books, notebooks, pens, pencils, etc. and to pay private coaching fees for her son’s education.
 
Minati and Krishna (in the photo) are very much thankful to BJS and Kiva for this educational loan.

loans.use: To pay tuition fees, private coaching fees and to purchase educational equipment for her son.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen is a 36-year-old married woman who has been running a business selling milk with her husband, who is also shown in the photo. She has one cow, which she uses for milk, selling to the people of her locality. She also sells butter and yogurt to generate an extra amount of profit. 

Parveen has become famous for providing good-quality milk and makes enough to contribute to her family's income. She has gradually improved her business with the support of the Kashf Foundation. Currently, she is in her third loan cycle, and has now applied for a loan of PKR 40,000. This will allow her to purchase one more cow. In this way, she will be able to increase her sales and profits alongside.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow.

loans.name: Puja Shg Group

texts.en:
The "Puja SHG" Self Help Group consists of nine members from a small village of Balugaon, Odisha, India. All the members of this group are female. They are engaged in different business activities for the elimination of poverty. Three of the women have very low incomes, but this helps them to want to struggle harder to get ahead.

One person who deserves to be highlighted is Tuni; in the picture she is the lady standing with hand raised, who works selling vegetables. Through her job, she works to support her family and also to improve her business and continue growing. She is a very determined person who wants to continue growing. She is seeking part of this group loan in order to be able to invest it in the purchase of vegetables like tomatoes, onions, green peppers, potatoes and other vegetables so that she can continue with her sales.

The group is very grateful for this opportunity for growth that it is receiving.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes, onions, green peppers, potatoes and other vegetables so that she can continue with her sales.

loans.name: Dusasan

texts.en:
Dusasan is a 35-year-old differently-able man who lives with his family in Puri, Odisha, India. Since 2009, Dusasan has been running a business near his house, and it is a very successful business for his family. He sells small pieces of wood and logs in bulk which are used for making fire and he also sells vegetables as a additional source of income.    He is currently in need of purchasing more wood, logs, and baskets to keep vegetables in. Due to financial constraints, he finds this difficult. 

Therefore, he has requested a loan of 20,000 INR from Kiva's partner, People's Forum. This will not only help him to grow his business but will also increase his net income and savings. He is very thankful to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To purchase logs, wood in bulk, and baskets for his vegetables business.

loans.name: Saraswati

texts.en:
Saraswati is a rural housewife of 48 years from the village West Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She has four children (two sons and two daughters).  She lives with her husband and children.  Saraswati is illiterate and only knows how to sign her name.  Her husband, Narayan, 51 years old, is also illiterate and can only sign his name.  They live in their own small kachha house (mud, straw and bamboo made). Their two daughters are married and two sons are engaged in small business.

Saraswati's husband is an experienced farmer. To take care of her family, Saraswati's husband works hard to overcome the financial hardship of their family. Saraswati assists her husband.  They sell the agricultural products in the local market, which is the family's main source of income.

To continue the business in a sustainable way, they need to expand their business.  They have decided to start a potato cultivation business. Saraswati applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to purchase fertilizers and potato seeds to start cultivation of potatoes. The loan will help her run her agribusiness in a productive way.

Her goals are to assist her husband to cover the expenses of their family and to purchase a piece of land with the profit generated from the business to use for cultivation.

She is thankful to her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers for cultivation of potatoes.

loans.name: Tulasi Asd Group

texts.en:
Damayanti is a 43-year-old lady who lives with her husband, parents-in-law and two children aged 15 years and 10 years in a small village in Odisha, India. In the picture, the lady standing with hand raised is Damayanti. She is engaged in paddy cultivation. Her husband is doing the same business.

Some years ago, Damayanti formed a group with nine other women from her village with the group name of "Tulasi ASD" self help group. All the group members are engaged in different business activities like selling milk, vegetable cultivation, etc to alleviate their poverty. Damayanti is the president of this group. She motivated all the group members to form this group so they could help and support each other in their business and personal lives.

Damayanti, along with her group, requested a loan of 250,000 INR. She will use her portion to purchase standard quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation.

She hopes to build a house for her family and she is very grateful to Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy (rice) cultivation.

loans.name: Ann Budhimaa Shg Group

texts.en:
Manju, the lady standing with raised hand in the photo, is a very active woman of 37 years of age. She resides in a small house with her husband and one son of 16 years in a rural village of Khurda district in Odisha, India.

For the last 12 years, Manju has run a general grocery shop in her small house with items like soap, shampoo, washing powder, sugar, tea, oil, etc. She started the business with a small investment of her own. At that time, her monthly net income was around 3,000 INR. It was very difficult on her part to maintain the family. So she, along with eight other women from her village, formed a self-help group named "Ann Budhimaa SHG" to access loans from People's Forum. Before that, she had taken out an individual loan from a micro finance institution and successfully repaid the total loan.  

Now she is earning a monthly income of 5,000 INR. As per the statement of Manju, this small income is not at all sufficient to manage the family along with educational expenses of her son, so she wants to increase her income by the expansion of her existing business. 

She has planned to use the loan amount to purchase items like rice, wheat, lentils, oil, soap, potatoes, etc.in bulk  for her general store. This will help her to reduce her purchasing and transportation costs as she will replenish her stock less frequently. She hopes that this investment will give her more income and enough savings so that she will be able to construct a house for her family, which is a dream for her, and give better education to their son. 

The other eight members of the group are running milk selling, computer center, and vegetable vending businesses.

loans.use: To purchase items like rice, wheat, lentils, oil, soap, potatoes, etc. in bulk for her general store.

loans.name: Chintamani

texts.en:
Chintamani is a forty-four-year-old differently able man with two children living in Puri, Odisha, India. He has been in the retail business for seven years, working in his village and doing farming as an additional income source.  Chintamani started in business to improve his family's lifestyle, and it enables him to buy all their basic needs. He sells toys near "Lord Jagannath" temple and also sells vegetables morning and evening. His wife helps him in this business.

His dream is to build a house for his family and he also wants to take a small place for his toy business. His income is affected by price fluctuations and sometimes by seasonal changes. Chintamani intends to use the loan to buy more toys in bulk from wholesalers.

He said, "I am grateful to KIVA and its lenders for this kind opportunity."

loans.use: To pay for more toys in bulk from wholesalers.

loans.name: Sandhya

texts.en:
Sandhya belongs to a conservative poor family. She can’t receive an education and remains illiterate, but knows how to sign her name. Her husband has a plywood business, selling plies in the village shops as well as in the wholesale market. Her two sons are students in class X (grade 10) and they are planning to work in their study field after graduation to start their work life. Because of the financial crisis Sandhya and her husband Pradeep are facing, they couldn't pay their son's tuition fees, school and examination fees. For this reason, she has applied for this loan to BJS (Kiva’s partner), an organization that gives financial assistance to poor families who have a low income. She is taking the loan for her son Partha, a 16-year-old boy in grade 10 who is appearing for his final board examinations. She will use the loan to buy his educational needs like books and uniforms and to pay his tuition fees, school and examination fees etc. It would enable her to cover all the expenses related to her children’s education and stabilize them in their study field. She also has a desire to make Partha a renowned doctor in the future.

Sandhya and Partha (standing next to her mother in the photo) are both grateful to BJS and Kiva for funding their educational loan.

loans.use: To buy educational equipment and to pay tuition fees for her son

loans.name: Ayomati

texts.en:
Ayomati, 29, lives in a remote region of West Bengal.  She lives in the small town of Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She lives with her husband and two sons. They live in their own small house. Ayomati is illiterate but knows how to sign her name. She could not receive education due to poverty, but she is willing to provide her children a higher education.

Her husband has been a van puller for many years and his earnings are hardly enough to cover the educational expenses of their children after managing the household expenses.  Her younger son, Shubhankar, is now studying in class VI (Grade 6) and very much serious with his studies as well as with his examinations. He is busy in his studies all day long as he has no private tutor.

Ayomati learned about BJS (Kiva’s partner) and applied for a loan of 15,000 INR for her son Shubhakar’s smooth education and for making him a deserving student in appearing for state board examination without any problem. With the loan amount she will pay the private tuition fee and buy necessary articles like books, notebooks, pen, geometry box, exercise copies, guide notes to let Shubhankar proceed a step forward for achieving good skill and knowledge. She wants her son to get the chance for admittance to a Bachelor of Arts class in future.

Ayomati and her son Shubhankar (as per photo) are grateful to BJS and Kiva for their support because Shubhankar is going ahead to higher classes without any monetary problems.

loans.use: To pay the tuition fees and buy necessary articles for her son’s educational purpose.

loans.name: Niyati

texts.en:
Niyati is a 53-year-old woman living in Dhupguri with her husband and two children. One of them is her son, Ranjit, of class X (grade 10), who is on the threshold of the secondary board examination. Both Niyati and her husband are illiterate and can sign their names only, but they are very much concerned in their children’s education.

Her husband is a farmer by profession and the family expenses are increasing gradually against their income. That is why some disputes arise in their children’s education. As Ranjit possess an outstanding merit, he might score high marks in the coming board exam, so to improve his educational skill and to give him proper tutorial help, Niyati is requesting a loan from BJS. This loan would help Ranjit to purchase educational equipment and to pay private tuition fees, so that he can receive education without any obstacle.
  
Ranjit in future wants to become a lawyer; this loan will help him to proceed towards his goal. Niyati and her elder son, Ranjit (pictured above), are thankful to BJS and Kiva for funding loan.

loans.use: To purchase educational equipment and to pay private tuition fees for her son’s education.

loans.name: Saraswati

texts.en:
Saraswati is a 44-year-old housewife whose husband Kobul is a farmer. Both of them are illiterate and can only sign their names, but give full inspiration to their children in their studies. They are blessed with three children and all of them are students in different classes. Her eldest daughter Kalyani is reading in class VIII (grade 8). She has obtained high marks in her previous annual examination and she is still doing marvelously well for her smooth promotion to the next class. 

The family’s financial condition is poor, Saraswati is unable to give Kalyani her private tuition for the subject she needs.  For this reason, Saraswati is taking a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to pay her daughter’s private tuition fees and school fees for her higher education, which will make her a responsible citizen. Kalyani’s aim is to be an engineer in the future. This loan will help Kalyani to progress towards her goal. Saraswati and her daughter (shown in the photo) are very much pleased with the loan and thank BJS and Kiva from the core of their heart.

loans.use: To pay private tuition fees and school fees for her daughter

loans.name: Dashami

texts.en:
Dashami is a 43-year-old housewife who lives in Raipara village at Dhupguri with her husband, Ratan, and two daughters. Her daughters are now reading in class VII (grade 7) and class III (grade 3).

Though Dashami is illiterate and only can sign her name, still she is very much interested to educate her children and make them good citizens. Her elder daughter, Sampa, reading in class VII (grade 7), is a very intelligent student and her good performances in school examinations inspire Dashami to take a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) for her schooling expenses. 

Her husband, Ratan, is involved in selling firewood to the village market but their inconsistent income makes them unable to go ahead with their daughter’s education. Dashami takes the loan to purchase Sampa’s text books, pens, study materials etc, to pay the school fees, tuitions fees, caution money and for other necessary educational dealings.

Now Dashami and her daughter Sampa (as in the picture) are very much grateful to BJS and Kiva for funding the educational loan.

loans.use: To pay for books, pens, study materials and tuition fees for her daughter’s schooling.

loans.name: Chhaya

texts.en:
Chhaya is a rural woman from the village of East Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri who lives in her own house. She lives with her husband Moloy and two children (one son and one daughter).  She is 45 years old and studied up to grade 8.  She is engaged in a cattle-raising business.  Her husband, age 51, attended school up to grade 7.  Their son and daughter are studying in grade 10 and grade 7.
 
Chhaya's husband is a greengrocer by profession. Currently, he works on a parcel of land in their village where he lives. What he produces is sold, so he can complement the income from his current job.  He is thriving, active and dynamic.  His persistence and positive attitude motivate him to seek new alternatives to upgrade his poor financial condition.

They have decided to start a milk products business.  For this reason, Chhaya is requesting a loan from BJS to buy a dairy cow. This will allow her to increase production and offer more products (milk. curd, butter, cheese, paneer etc.) for sale.  She will be able to meet the household expenses with the income. Moreover, she will be able to give her children a proper education with the profit generated from this business.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow to start a dairy products business.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby is the mother of three children. She lives in Roypara village in Dhupguri. In spite of being illiterate, she is highly interested in her children’s education. All three of them are regular good student in class X (grade 10), class IX (grade 9) and class VI (grade 6).

Mahananda (Ruby’s son) is the youngest child in the family of five members. His mother is simply a housewife and his father is a hocker. In the photo, Mahananda is standing next to his mother. He is a student in class VI (grade 6). His father, Moti, is facing difficulties in paying Mahananda’s tuition fees after meeting the educational expenses of his two older children. This is a vital problem for him because his two children are going to complete their school education and his youngest child, though reading in a lower class, is very sincere about his studies and school curriculum. 

Ruby has been unable to take care of all the things they need. She thanks BJS (Kiva’s partner) for helping her with a loan that will resolve this dilemma. She is an honest woman and is requesting a loan of INR 15,000 to buy education tools for Mahananda and pay his the tuition fees.

She hopes that her children will have a stable job after they complete their bachelor's degree. It has been a help for her children’s education and to Dhupguri’s youth generation in general, so Ruby and her son Mahananda (shown in the picture) are now very happy about getting the loan from BJS and Kiva and both of them are thankful to the lenders.

loans.use: To pay tuitions fees and to purchase educational tools for her son

loans.name: Rina

texts.en:
Rina, 46, is from the countryside and lives happily with her husband and their only son.  They are from the small town of Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. Both of them attended school up to grade 8.  They live in their own concrete house.

Rina’s husband is engaged in the business of buying and selling coconuts.  He buys coconuts from his village and neighboring villages and sells them in the local market.  Coconut is in great demand in his area and is a very popular fruit used in most Bengali sweets.  Rina has always been an exemplary housewife who helps her husband in his work after managing her household works. Their son is also engaged in this business. All of them work hard with the aim of improving the family income because they are in a very difficult situation.

Therefore, Rina has decided to develop their coconut business and applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS to purchase more stocks of coconut. She hopes, with her tenacity and perseverance, she will be able to succeed and overcome the obstacles, especially the growing prices of essential commodities.

In the future, she dreams of buying a cycle van to carry the products to the market.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more coconuts to sell

loans.name: Feroza

texts.en:
Feroza is a 39-year-old married woman. She is a homemaker. Her husband Rafiqul, aged 42 years, is a farmer by trade and earns money by selling his farmed vegetables and crops to the village market. Both of them are illiterate, can sign their names only. Feroza is a mother of three children. They are receiving an education. Amongst them, two children study in class IX (Grade9) and class X (Grade10) respectively. They live in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri in their own semi-pakka (concrete walls with a thatched roof) house.

Feroza needs a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) so that she can buy seeds and fertilizers for potato cultivation and make a good profit from this business. She hopes to upgrade their financial condition and give a good upbringing to their children. There is a very good demand for potatoes in this area, so the business will be a lucrative one. She wants to become financially successful from this business. 

Feroza and her husband dream of upgrading their semi-pakka house to a brick-built house and want to buy more agricultural lands for cultivation with the profit from this business.

Her full thanks go to BJS as well as to Kiva for giving her the loan.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds and fertilizers for cultivating potatoes.

loans.name: Tanuka

texts.en:
Tanuka is a 40-year-old housewife.  She is from the small village of Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.  Her husband Dhirendranath is a cycle-van puller by profession. Both Tanuka and her husband are uneducated and can only sign their names. Tanuka's husband earns for the family by carrying goods and people in his van.  He is the only earning member of the family. They live in their own kachha house (bamboo, straw and mud made). They have only one son who is a student in grade 9.

Their son Toton is brilliant in his studies.  He is only 16 years old but really passionate about mathematics.  He hopes to go for higher studies in mathematics.  If he could have received private tuition, then he could have done much better in his final examination. Tanuka is very eager to give her son all kinds of support, but is unable to do so for the lack of money, so she is requesting an education loan for her son to buy education supplies like books, pens, pencils, notebooks etc. and to pay for her son's tuition fees, school fees etc.

Tanuka and her son (in the photo) are very happy and thankful to BJS and Kiva for this educational loan.

loans.use: To pay school fees, tuition fees and purchase educational supplies

loans.name: Anima

texts.en:
Anima is a housewife in a small village in Dhupguri (Roypara) in the district of Jalpaiguri.  Anima and her husband Surendranath are illiterate and only know how to sign their names. They have three children who are engaged in study. They live in a kaccha house (made of straw and mud).

Anima’s husband Surendranath sells timber to the market as well as in the locality.  Anima and her husband decided to take this loan of INR 15,000 to invest in their existing timber business to purchase more timber, wood, logs of wood etc. for their business.  There is a high demand for timber in their locality as there are only a few timber shops in that area. Demand in the locality is the main reason for expanding their existing business. Anima is confident that she will be financially stable if she can expand the business with the loan. It will also enable her to build a pakka (concrete) house with the profit they will earn from their business. 

They are thankful to both Kiva and BJS for the loan, which will help them to enhance their existing business.

loans.use: To purchase timber to sell

loans.name: Bachiran

texts.en:
Bachiran is a 28-year-old housewife and there are two children and her husband in her family. Her husband Bacchu is 38 years old.  Both of them are illiterate and can only sign their names.  Their two children are receiving an education. They study in class I (Grade 1) and class IV (Grade 4). Bachiran and her husband have their own kaccha house (straw and mud-made) at Stationpara in the small town Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri.

Bachiran’s husband cultivates different crops in their own small piece of land.  He has been working with agriculture for many years and produces beans, onions and other vegetables for the family's consumption and to retail in the local bazaar.

The small income of Bachiran's husband is not sufficient to get over the financial hurdles of their family, so she decided to start cultivating potatoes in their land. For this she needs capital, so she applied for the loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) for purchasing good quality potato seeds and fertilizers.  She hopes the profit, which will be generated from their new business will meet the financial needs of their family as well as help her to give her children better education. She hopes to upgrade their kachha house to a Pacca one (made of concrete) in future.

She thanks BJS and Kiva very much for funding the loan.

loans.use: To purchase good quality potato seeds and fertilizers for cultivating potatoes.

loans.name: Arati

texts.en:
Arati is a 36-year-old housewife.  She is married to Jaykanti and they are raising one son together. They live in their own house in Maynaguri town in the district of Jalpaiguri. She and her husband both have completed their education up to class VIII (grade 8). Her son didn’t get the chance to receive an education due to their poverty.

Arati started her business of selling sarees (an Indian dress) a few years ago to generate some income for her family. She sells sarees mainly to her friends, neighbors, and acquaintances. Her saree business is not running properly as the prices of sarees are going up daily. She would like to get a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to buy a variety of sarees and expand her business to meet her customer's needs and to upgrade their financial condition. The profits generated will be used to build her savings to purchase a shop in the local market in order to expand her business. She is a lady with great enthusiasm and never wants to stop fighting for her business. 

She is very much grateful to BJS and Kiva for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of sarees (an Indian dress) to sell

loans.name: Chabita

texts.en:
Chabita is a 19-year-old woman who lives with her husband, Dipu, and one child in Dhupguri. Her child is too small to go to school. Chabita is a homemaker while her husband is a farmer and sells different vegetables in the market. 

Their income is so inconsistent that she is unable to cover the household expenses, but Chabita dreams of providing her child with a proper education and make him responsible and a good citizen. She decided to cultivate broad beans with the other vegetables on her own land as there is a great demand for broad beans now and she will be able to generate more income for her family. She is confident that she will grow her business with the profit she will earn from her business.

She requested a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase seeds, fertilizers, pesticides etc. for growing broad beans, which will ultimately help in generating more income. They live in a kaccha house (made of mud and straw), so in the future, she wants to build a concrete house with the profit from her business. She is so enthusiastic that she will be able to meet her expectations.

Her best regards go to BJS and Kiva as well for the loan.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers to grow broad beans

loans.name: Swapna

texts.en:
Swapna is a rural hardworking woman who stays with her husband and three children in a small house in Dhupguri. Sudipta is the elder daughter of Swapna. Recently, she was promoted to class XI (grade 11) under the West Bengal Board of Higher Secondary Education. 

Swapna and her husband, Harekrishna, face a lot of financial difficulties to bear the educational costs of their children. They generate a small income from their small firewood business.

Swapna’s son, Sudipta, plans to complete his higher secondary examination (grade 12) in December 2015 with good marks, and take admission to a good college. Due to the lack of family income, Swapna could not afford the proper tuition and to buy books. So, she decided to take an educational loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS, to purchase her son’s textbooks, notebooks, test papers, etc., and to pay the tuition fees for his uninterrupted education. 
 
With this loan amount, her son can buy books and hopes to understand his subjects better. Swapna is now quite confident with her son’s education, and Sudipto is also very happy after getting the loan for his studies. 

Swapna, along with her son Sudipta (shown in the picture), are highly grateful to BJS and Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: to meet the costs of her son's education.

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Sabita and her husband both have completed their education up to primary level. Her husband, Kartick, aged 39 years, is engaged in cultivation. Their children are receiving education and read in grade 6 and grade 5.

Sabita could not complete her education due to poverty, but she is willing to provide her children a higher education and desires that her children do not face any obstacle in receiving education. Sabita’s husband has been associated with agricultural activities for many years, but his income is hardly enough to cover all the expenses, especially the educational expenses of their children.

Sabita’s son, Lakhsman, is in grade 6 now. He is a very meritorious and studious boy.  He wants to go for higher education in the future. But, because of the financial crisis, Sabita and her husband cannot provide his school fees, necessary articles and private tuition. 

Sabita learned about BJS and applied for a loan for her son's uninterrupted education. With the loan amount, she will pay the private tuition fees and school fees, and buy necessary articles like books, notebooks, pens, geometry box, etc. for educational purposes for her son.

Sabita and her family are very much grateful to Kiva and BJS for this loan.

loans.use: to pay the tuition fees and buy necessary articles for her son's education.

loans.name: Endali

texts.en:
Endali is a 48-year-old housewife who lives with her husband and one son in Dhupguri. Both she and her husband are illiterate, but can sign their names.

By profession, her husband is a farmer. Due to their illiteracy, they are unable to engage themselves in any other work that can generate more income. They have their own land and experience in the agricultural field, so this is the reason for choosing this business.  

Endali wishes to cultivate broad beans on her own land to generate more income.  With this loan amount, she wants to buy bean seeds and fertilizers to grow a bean crop. Endali is confident that she will be able to grow her business.

They don’t have a concrete house, so in the future she wants to build a concrete house with the profit she earns from her business. She is a lady with great enthusiasm, and she has started dreaming of purchasing a tractor for fresh and good cultivation in the future.

Endali is very much grateful to Kiva and BJS for this loan.

loans.use: to buy broad bean seeds and fertilizers to cultivate broad beans.

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Sabita is a 39-year-old woman who lives with her husband and three children (two sons and one daughter).  She is married to Dinanath, who is engaged in a milk supply business. Sabita is uneducated and can only sign her name, while her husband attended school up to grade 6. They live in their own house in the small village of Magurmari in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. All their children are getting an education. Sabita's husband supplies milk door to door in his neighborhood. His income is so scanty that it has become impossible for him to continue their children's education in addition to covering household expenses.

Sabita's son Nonigopal is a meritorious and sincere student. He is very serious with his studies as well as with his examinations.  He makes himself busy all day long, as he has no private tutor. He wants to become an engineer in the future.

Sabita has learned about BJS and has taken a loan from them for her son's smooth education. With the loan, she will pay the private tuition fees and school fees and buy necessary articles for his education so that her son can proceed towards achieving his goal.

Sabita and her son are very much thankful to BJS as well as Kiva for their support because Nonigopal is going ahead to higher classes without any monetary hindrance.

loans.use: To pay school tuition fees, private tuition fees and other educational expenses

loans.name: Tamina

texts.en:
Tamina is a 51-year-old widow from a small village, Baroghoria, in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She is an uneducated woman and can only sign her name. She lost her husband few years ago. From then on, she has been working hard. 

She has been working as a daily labourer under a building contractor in order to look after her only son. Now her son is engaged in agriculture on their small piece of land. Tamina and her son live in their own small kachha house (mud, straw and bamboo-made) with a lot of difficulties.

Tamina and her son work on their land from dawn to dusk and grow vegetables, which he sells in the local market. Both Tamina and her son do hard labour, but are unable to give sufficient sustenance to the family. They want to expand their agribusiness by cultivating potatoes, but for that they need some capital. Tamina is taking a loan to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers. She has chosen this business because there is a large demand for potatoes in her area, as well as throughout the West Bengal region.

She wishes to obtain financial sustenance through this business and give her son a better lifestyle. She wishes to employ some rural women to assist her in sowing and harvesting potato seeds, so that she can obtain good-quality potatoes to sell in the village market. 

Her dream is to buy a tractor for better cultivation in the future with the profit generated from this business.

She gladly thanks BJS and Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers for cultivation.

loans.name: Haseena

texts.en:
Haseena is 22 years old, married, and raising two children (one son and one daughter) with her husband.  Haseena has an education of primary level, but her husband, Rashidul, aged 24 years, attended school up to grade 8.  Both their son and daughter are receiving education and read in grade 4 and grade 1 respectively. They live in their own house in the small village of Baroghoria in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri .

Haseena 's husband is engaged in agriculture. He grows different vegetables in different seasons and sells them in the local market. For additional income, Haseena is involved in animal husbandry. In spite of the hard labour of Haseena and her husband, they are unable to cover all the necessary expenses incurred in their family, especially the educational expenses of their children.

In order to grow her business, Haseena has taken a loan to purchase a cow. She has decided to start a dairy products business (milk, paneer, cheese, etc.) and will sell the products in her neighbourhood. She hopes to earn much profit as the products are in great demand in the market.

Haseena plans to invest income from the loan to give a decent lifestyle to her family, to further grow the number of domestic animals, to save money for her children's education, and last but not the least, to build a concrete-made house for them.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva for fulfilling her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow to start a milk and milk products business.

loans.name: Ajima

texts.en:
Ajima is a 33-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband, Tajamol, and three children at Khagrabari in the small town of Maynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. Ajima is a housewife, and she received education up to class VI (grade 6). Her husband studied up to class V (Grade 5). Their children are receiving education and facing many difficulties in their own one-room, kaccha house (made of straw and mud).

Her husband is a cycle-van puller. He works hard, and carries goods from one place to another with the help of his cycle-van. He sometimes rents the van for transportation, but he has to face tough competition from the other van pullers, and he does not get enough profit to cope with the financial stringency to run his family well. 

Ajima wants to start a dairy products business to give financial support to her husband and family. Ajima heard that Kiva’s partner, BJS, offers loans to women in the community to start businesses, so she applied for a loan to help her husband to buy a cow. She plans to supply milk, as well as dairy products, in the locality. There is a good demand for milk and dairy products in their locality.

Ajima hopes that the profit she will get from the business will give good support to upgrade their financial condition and to give her children a better education. Her dream is to make a pacca (brick-built) house instead of living in a kaccha house.

She gives hearty thanks to the lenders of this loan.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and start a dairy products business.

loans.name: Malati

texts.en:
Malati, a 26-year-old housewife, lives in the small village of Baroghoria in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri with her husband Haridas who is 28 years old.  They are blessed with two sons. Both their sons are school going and read in grade 4 and grade 6.  Malati and her husband both are illiterate and can only sign their names. She is a homemaker and her husband is engaged the business of making bamboo baskets. He sells the baskets in the local market.  His business is the only source of income for the family.  But he is not able to make sufficient income from his business.  They are very much concerned about their children's proper education and about earning their livelihood.

Now, Malati has decided to help her husband. She is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner BJS to purchase more bamboo to expand their business. They hope this will enable them to keep all the profits and improve the family's future.  Demand for this type of basket is high in their area. The high volume of work will create a steady income so that Malati can give her sons a bright future.

She aspires to upgrade their kachha house (bamboo, mud and straw made) to a concrete-made house, with the profit generated from this business.

She is highly obliged to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to make baskets

loans.name: Mamuda

texts.en:
Mamuda is a caring mother of two children (one son and one daughter).  She is a 27-year-old housewife who is illiterate.  Her husband Abedul is also illiterate and is a farmer by profession. He is 31 years old and extensively engaged in cultivation to give a better lifestyle to his family. Their children are getting an education and are in grade 7 and grade 5.  They live in the small village of Baroghoria in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri in their own small kachha house (mud, bamboo and straw made).

Though Mamuda and her husband are illiterate, they are very much interested in educating their children and making them good citizens. Her daughter Ruksana, reading in grade 7, is a very intelligent student and her good performance in school inspires Mamuda to take a loan from BJS for her educational expenses. Her husband's inconsistent income makes them unable to go ahead with their daughter's education.

Mamuda took the loan to purchase Ruksana's text books, school uniform, pens, pencils, and other study materials and to pay the school fees, tuition fees, caution money (security deposit) and other necessary educational dealings.

Mamuda and her daughter (in the picture) are very much happy and grateful to BJS and Kiva for funding their educational loan.

loans.use: To pay school fees, tuition fees, and other educational expenses.

loans.name: Krishna

texts.en:
Krishna, age 28 is a courageous lady from a village of Dhupguri. She lives with her husband, Bablu. They are illiterate and are only able to sign their names. 

Krishna’s husband has a small grocery shop. It was difficult for them to manage the minimum day-to-day expenses of the livelihood of her family, as the income from the grocery shop is very low. Krishna decided to expand her own grocery shop, but due to lack of funds, it was very difficult for them. Then she heard about BJS and decided to take a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) for purchasing a variety of groceries for her grocery shop.  

In the future, she dreams to extend her business and build a big concrete grocery shop with the profit from her business. She is highly obliged to BJS and Kiva for funding her without any hesitation.

loans.use: to buy grocery items for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Minati

texts.en:
Minati is a 40-year-old woman from the remote village of Jhumurpara in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.  She is married to Bhabesh who is 45 years old and engaged in an agribusiness. Both of them completed their primary education. They are blessed with three school-going children (one son and two daughters), who are in grade 11, grade 8 and grade 5, respectively. They live in their own house.

One of her daughters, Madhabi, is in class VIII (grade 8).  Both Manati and her husband are very much concerned about their children's education. Their family expenses are increasing day by day and it is not possible for Minati's husband to meet all the expenses of the family with his small income. That's why some disputes have arisen about their children's education. As Madhabi possesses outstanding merit, she might score high in the annual examination. So to improve her educational skills and to give her proper private tuition, Minati is requesting an educational loan from BJS.  This loan will help Minati to provide her daughter with educational equipment such as books, notebooks, pens. pencils, geometry box etc, and to pay the school fees and private tuition fees, so that she can receive an education without any obstacles.

Madhabi, in the future, wants to be a schoolteacher, which she considers the most noble profession and this loan will help her to fulfill her dream.

Minati and Madhabi (in the picture ) are thankful to BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase educational supplies and to pay private tuition fees for her daughter

loans.name: Fani

texts.en:
Fani is a very courageous 46-year-old woman with many hopes. She is a housewife of Dhupguri town and the mother of a son who keeps himself busy in farming along with his father. She and her husband are both illiterate, but know how to sign their names.

Fani’s husband is a farmer. He has an agricultural business. They have land where her husband cultivates different seasonal vegetables and sells them to the market. Fani also assists her husband in this work. 

Now they want to cultivate broad beans on this land, as per the demand of their local market and because it is the best season to cultivate broad beans. She is requesting this loan to buy broad bean seeds, fertilizers and pesticides to cultivate broad beans, avoiding contamination of insects and diseases.

She hopes broad bean cultivation will give her extensive financial support in the near future and will produce a more helpful environment, which is lacking in her family.

Now Fani is very happy about getting the loan and gives her heartiest thanks to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for broad beans cultivation.

loans.name: Alfa

texts.en:
Alfa is a woman of the age of 44 years. She lives in a small village, Baroghoria, in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She is illiterate and can only sign her name. She is married to Akkel, who is 57 years old and a farmer by profession. Alfa lives happily with her husband and only son in their own house.

Alfa's husband and son both are engaged in cultivation of different seasonal vegetables on their ancestral land. Their agribusiness is the main source of income for the family. Alfa is also a wholehearted, good and industrious woman. She has an animal husbandry. She has a dairy cow, which gives milk every day, and she sells this to neighbours and friends. The income from this type of business is stable, but small. To lead a decent life, they have to earn more money. Therefore, Alfa wants to increase the number of cows so that she can increase the income from this business.

Alfa came to know about BJS and that they give loans to rural women to start businesses. She has taken a loan from BJS to purchase another cow and start a dairy products business (milk, butter, paneer, curd, etc.).  She hopes she will earn extra profit from this business, as the products are in huge demand in today's market.

She dreams to overcome the financial hurdles of their family and to purchase more cows with the profit, in order to expand her business.

She gives her thanks to her lenders (BJS and Kiva) for the loan.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow to expand her existing milk-supply business.

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi is a 32-year-old married woman having two daughters and her husband is 37 years old. She has read up to class VIII (grade 8) and her husband has completed secondary education. They live in the small town of Maynaguri. Their children are studying in class VIII (grade 7) and class XI (grade 11).

Laxmi is engaged in paddy cultivation, while her husband has a small business. She harvests paddy and sells to the market. She has chosen this activity because they own a plot of land and farming on one’s own land is much more profitable than harvesting crop on some other land. The land Laxmi owns is perfect for harvesting paddy. She took out a loan from Kiva's partner Belghoria Janakalyan Samity (BJS) to purchase seeds and fertilizers for farming paddy in her own field. Last year she had a good harvest of paddy from her land and she hopes this year also to have a good harvest.

Laxmi is highly obliged to BJS and Kiva for the financial support to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers for paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Sakila

texts.en:
Sakila is a 38-year-old housewife who is uneducated and can only sign her name.  She is married to Taiyab, 47 years old, illiterate and engaged in a small business. They have three beautiful children (one son and two daughters). All of them are students. They live in the small village of Jhumurpara in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. They have a small house.

Her husband is engaged in a small business. His income is so scanty that he is unable to give sufficient financial sustenance to the family. The family expenses are increasing rapidly day by day against their income.  As a result, it has become impossible for him to pay the educational expenses of their children, so they are thinking of discontinuing their education.

Sakila’s daughter Taslima is a student in grade 9.  She is a very brilliant and studious girl. If she could have private tuition or coaching, then she would do much better in her final exam. All the teachers at her school are waiting for her outstanding results in the final exam. Sakila has taken the loan from BJS to support her daughter's education.  The loan would help her to purchase educational supplies like books, notebooks, pens, pencils, geometry box etc. and to pay the fees for school and for the private tutor.

Sakila and her daughter (in the photo) are very much thankful to BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase school supplies and pay school fees and private tuition fees.

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
Sumitra is a 27-year-old married lady and her husband Santosh is 33 years old. They have two children (one son and one daughter). They are receiving education; their son is in class V (grade 5) and their daughter is in class VII (Grade 7). Sumitra is a homemaker and her husband is a farmer. Both of them are illiterate but know how to sign their name. Sumitra's husband’s income is not sufficient to support their family. To make more income for her family, she decided to start her new business of eggplant cultivation so she applied for a loan. They have their own vacant land which is near their home. Sumitra used to work over there but due to financial conditions she couldn’t continue. Now with this loan amount she will buy eggplant seeds and fertilizer for cultivating eggplants and sell the eggplants in the market.

Her future dream is to build their own pakka house (concrete house) as now they live in a kachha house (a house made of mud and straw) with profit from her business. She is very happy after becoming a member of BJS and grateful to Kiva for funding her loan.

loans.use: To purchase eggplant seeds and fertilizers for growing eggplants.

loans.name: Maleka

texts.en:
Maleka is 38 years old.  She is a woman from the remote village of Jhumurpara in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She is a housewife and uneducated. She can only sign her name. Her husband Rafikul, age 47, is engaged in a small business. He is also illiterate. They are blessed with three children (one son and two daughters). Maleka and her husband are providing an education for them.  They are in grade 9, grade 5 and grade 4, respectively.  They live in their own kachha house (mud, bamboo and straw made).

They are willing to provide her children with a higher education and desire that they do not face any obstacles in receiving this education.

Maleka's husband has been associated with a small business for many years.  His earnings are hardly sufficient to cover the educational expenses of their children after meeting the household expenses of the family.

Maleka's daughter Rokeya is now studying in grade 9 and very much serious about her studies. She aims to be a doctor in the future.

Maleka learned about BJS and applied for a loan for her daughter's uninterrupted education. With the loan, will pay the private tuition fees and school fees and buy supplies like books, notebooks, pens, pencils, geometry box etc. for educational purposes for her daughter.

Maleka and her daughter (in the photo) are very glad and obliged to Kiva and BJS for this loan. They give hearty thanks to them.

loans.use: To pay tuition fees and purchase educational supplies for her daughter.

loans.name: Ratna

texts.en:
Ratna is a 38-year-old married woman with two children, and her husband is 38 years old. Both of them have completed class VIII (grade 8) standard. Each of their children is studying in the village school but in different classes. Ratna lives in the small town of Maynaguri.

Ratna's husband Shyamal has a small business, but his income is not enough. Providing education for two children and running a household is very difficult for them, so Ratna decided to generate some income on her own, and contribute to her family. In her childhood she learned stitching and knitting so she thought to do this as her business for now. She thought to buy a sewing machine so that she can improve her skill and earn money to improve their piteous financial condition.

 For this reason she has applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) and she has already started to take orders for preparing new kinds of dresses. She hopes she will be able to remove her family’s financial discrepancy with the profit from her business and in future she can succeed in life.

Ratna thanks BJS and Kiva earnestly for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine to start her new tailoring business.

loans.name: Kanta

texts.en:
Kanta is a 34-year-old married woman with two children from Maynaguri and her husband is 37 years old. Her husband has completed class VIII (grade 8) and she is illiterate but knows to sign her name. 

Her husband is engaged in a small business but his income is not enough for the family. Providing education for two children and running a household is very difficult for them, so Kanta decided to weave Tant sarees (Tant saree is a traditional Indian saree, usually used by Bengali women) and sell them in her locality so that she can also earn money and contribute to her family. In her childhood she learned stitching, knitting and weaving of Tant sarees so she wants to apply her knowledge through this, as her business. 

Kanta thought to buy a weaving machine so that she can improve her skill & generate more income. For this reason she has applied for a loan and she has already started to take orders for making decorative sarees and hopes she will succeed in her life by selling those sarees at a moderate price. There is a great demand for Tant sarees throughout the Bengal. 

Kanta is very much thankful to BJS and Kiva for funding her to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase a weaving machine for her business of making Tant sarees.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina is 36 years old and lives in a remote region in West Bengal.  She lives in the small town of Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.  She lives with her husband Robiul and their three children (one son and two daughters). All of the children are students. They are in grade 10, grade 11 and in college, respectively. They live in their own small kachha house (mud, straw and bamboo made). Sakina has an education up to grade 6.  Her husband Robiul, age 40, has been a car driver for many years and his earnings are hardly enough to cover the educational expenses of their children after managing the household expenses. They want to give their children a higher education.

Her son Sahazad is now studying in grade 11 and very serious about his studies as well as his examinations. He makes himself busy with his studies all day long, as he has no private tutor.

Sakina heard about BJS and applied for a loan for her son's smooth education to make him a deserving student when he appears in the board exam.  She wants to pay the private tuition fees and buy the necessary supplies like books, notebooks, pens, pencils etc. to let Sahazad proceed a step further towards achieving good skills and knowledge. She wants her son to get a chance at the Joint Entrance Exam to become a doctor.

Sakina and her son (in the photo) are grateful to BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To pay tuition fees and buy necessary supplies for her sons's education.

loans.name: Fajiran

texts.en:
